greeting: Greetings from The On-Line Encyclopedia of Integer Sequences! http://oeis.org/

results.name: Smallest number having exactly n representations as sum of two squares of distinct primes.
comment: No terms after a(13) are smaller than 99000000. - _John W. Layman_, Jan 20 2004
link: Donovan Johnson, Table of n, a(n) for n = 0..33 (terms < 10^12)
Index entries for sequences related to sums of squares
mathematica: (* This program is not convenient for a large number of terms *) nMax = 14; piMax = 2500; tp = Table[{Prime[i]^2 + Prime[j]^2, i, j}, {i, 1, piMax}, {j, i+1, piMax}] // Flatten[#, 1]&; sp = tp[[All, 1]] // Tally // Sort[#, #1[[2]] > #2[[2]]& ]& // Split[#, #1[[2]] == #2[[2]]& ]&; ssp = (Sort /@ sp)[[All, 1]]; a[0] = 1; Do[a[ssp[[n, 2]]] = ssp[[n, 1]], {n, 1, Length[ssp]}]; Table[a[n], {n, 0, nMax}] (* _Jean-François Alcover_, Jun 19 2013 *)
results.author: _Reinhard Zumkeller_, Oct 23 2003
ext: More terms from _John W. Layman_, Jan 20 2004
